data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Optical Properties of Semiconductors
data.description: Reflection and refraction of electromagnetic waves at dielectric and conducting interfaces. Dispersion, absorption processes, photo effects, magneto-optical effects, emission of radiation.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Photoconductivity and Luminescence
data.description: Electron processes in crystals, photoconductive processes. Electrode effects, imperfection and energy band transitions, scattering traps and trapping effects. Recombination kinetics, luminescence. Experimental methods and analysis.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electricity and Magnetism
data.description: Supplemental course material in Electricity and Magnetism for preparation of upper year courses in this discipline. [Offered: W,S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Scattering Theory
data.description: Review of potential theory of scattering. Applications chosen from elastic and inelastic neutron, X-ray, light, charged-particle, and atomic and molecular beam scattering.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Pre-University Physics
data.description: This course covers the topics in Ontario Secondary Schools essential for first year university physics. Topics include: motion in one and two dimensions using vectors as appropriate, Newton's laws of motion applied using free body diagrams, energy, geometric optics, simple waves in one and two dimensions, electrical and magnetic effects. Successful completion of this course fulfils the University admission requirements where high school Physics is necessary. No University Credit. Offered by Distance Education only.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Physics Seminar
data.description: This seminar brings together Physics students in all years to hear invited speakers, view physics-related films, and learn about current research. [Offered: F,W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Physics 1
data.description: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
data.notes: [Note: Science students must also take PHYS 111L. Offered: F, W; also offered online: W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Physics 1 Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 111.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternate weeks. Offered: F]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Physics 2
data.description: A continuation of PHYS 111; includes simple harmonic motion, electrostatic force and potential, electric current and power, DC circuits, magnetic field and induction, wave motion, sound and optics.
data.prerequisites: PHYS 111 or 121;
data.notes: [Note: Science students must also take PHYS 112L. Offered: W,S; also offered online: S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Physics 2 Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 112.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternates weeks. Offered: W,S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Mechanics
data.description: Brief review of kinematics. Particle dynamics, work, energy, conservation of energy. Conservation of linear momentum, collisions, rotational kinematics and dynamics, conservation of angular momentum. Equilibrium of rigid bodies. [Offered: F]
data.antirequisites: PHYS 111, 121; First year Engineering students only

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Mechanics
data.description: An introductory course in physics for students intending to concentrate their future studies in the physical sciences, optometry or mathematics; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, forces in nature, work and energy, conservation of energy and linear momentum, rotational kinematics and dynamics, and conservation of angular momentum.
data.notes: [Note: Successful completion of 4 U Calculus and Vectors , 4U Advanced Functions and 4U Physics is required. Science students must also take PHYS 121L (or PHYS 131L if they intend to follow any Physics or Mathematical Physics Plan). Students in Honours Life Physics, Biophysics Specialization, are encouraged to take PHYS 111L. Offered: F, also offered online: W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Mechanics Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 121. Students intending to follow a Physics or Mathematical Physics plan must take PHYS 131L.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternates weeks. Offered: F]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Waves, Electricity and Magnetism
data.description: Simple harmonic motion, resonance, damped harmonic motion, wave motion and sound, electrostatic force and potential, electric current and power, capacitors, DC circuits, LRC circuits, introduction to magnetic fields Lorentz Force.
data.prerequisites: PHYS 111 (minimum grade 70%) or PHYS 115 or 121 or ECE 105.
data.notes: [Note: Science students must also take PHYS 122L (or PHYS 132L if they intend to follow any Physics or Mathematical Physics plan). Offered: W,S; also offered online: S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Scientific Computer Programming
data.description: Introduction to scientific computer programming techniques as applied to problem solving in physics, with examples from first year mechanics. Simple sequential programs, control structures, functions, data types, data storage and scientific graphing. Introduction to object oriented programming. Numerical differentiation, integration, root determination and solution of linear equation systems. [Offered: W. The last offering of this course will be winter 2011.]
data.prerequisites: Not open to students in Mathematics.
terms_offered: W. The last offering of this course will be winter 2011

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Waves, Electricity and Magnetism Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 122. Students intending to follow a Physics or Mathematical Physics plan must take PHYS 132L.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternate weeks. Offered: W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Modern Physics
data.description: An introductory course in modern physics; includes relativity, quantum physics, atomic physics, nuclear physics, particle physics and gravitation. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 111 (minimum grade 70%) or 115 or 121 or ECE 105.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Physics for Engineers
data.description: Oscillations; simple harmonic motion. Wave motion, travelling and standing waves; transverse and longitudinal waves, including sound. Geometrical optics; reflection and refraction. Physical optics; interference and diffraction. Quantum physics; quantization of radiation; hydrogen atom. [Offered: W,S]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 115; Engineering students only.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Mechanics Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 121 and who intend to follow a Physics or Mathematical Physics plan; all other students who have taken or are taking PHYS 121 should select PHYS 121L.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternate weeks. Offered: F]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Waves, Electricity, Magnetism and Measurement Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 122 and who intend to follow a Physics or Mathematical Physics plan; all other students who have taken or are taking PHYS 122 should select PHYS 122L.
data.prerequisites: Chemical Physics, Life Physics, Materials and Nanosciences, Mathematical Physics, Physics, and Physics and Astronomy students only.
data.notes: [Note: Lab runs each week. Offered: W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Introduction to the Universe
data.description: A survey course in astrophysics intended for Physics and Astronomy students. Astrophysical processes, the sky, the Sun, stars, black holes, the Milky Way and other galaxies, Big Bang cosmology.
data.notes: [Note: students in any Physics and Astronomy or Astrophysics specialization programs must also take PHYS 175L; Offered: W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Introduction to the Universe Laboratory
data.description: For students who are taking PHYS 175. [Offered: W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electricity and Magnetism 1
data.description: Coulomb's law, electric field, Gauss' law, potential, capacitance, properties of dielectrics, current, resistance, electromotive force, D.C. circuits and instruments. [Offered: F]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electricity and Magnetism 2
data.description: Magnetic fields, induced electromotive forces, magnetic properties of matter, alternating currents, electromagnetic waves. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 222.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electricity and Magnetism for Life and Medical Physics
data.description: Coulomb's law, electric field, Gauss' law, potential, current, resistance, electromotive force, D.C. circuits, magnetic fields, induced electromotive forces; applications include cell membrane potentials, action potentials, role of charge in structure and function of DNA, basis for the magneto-encephalogram and biomedical instrumentations. [Offered: F]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electricity and Magnetism Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 224; only for Honours Life Physics students taking the Medical Physics Specialization.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternate weeks. Offered: F]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Modeling Life Physics
data.description: Introduction to modeling living systems and their components. Statistical methods in data analysis, curve fitting, including p values. Fourier series and transforms, structural analysis, including nearest neighbor distributions in biomedical applications. Introduction to methods for analysis of transport properties in biological systems. Use of computers in these areas. [Offered: F]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Geometrical Optics
data.description: Fermat's principle, reflection and refraction at plane and spherical surfaces, thin and thick lenses, optical instruments such as magnifiers, microscopes, telescopes, spectrometers, normal magnification. [Offered: F]
data.prerequisites: One of PHYS 111, 121 and One of PHYS 112, 122; One of MATH 107, 127, 137, 147 and One of MATH 108, 128, 138, 148.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Measurement Laboratory
data.description: A laboratory that teaches programming (e.g.LabVIEW) for the computer interfacing of physics experiments and automatic data collection.
data.prerequisites: PHYS 132L and restricted to students in Physics, Chemical Physics, Science and Business (Physics Option), Materials and Nanosciences
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternate weeks. Offered: Fall].

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
data.description: Introduction to quantization, wave-particle duality and the uncertainty principle The Schroedinger equation and solvable examples. Topics will include stationary states of particle-in-a-box, harmonic oscillator and the hydrogen atom. Quantization of angular momentum and spin. Introduction to approximation methods including time-independent perturbation theory. Modern applications of quantum mechanics. [Offered: W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Quantum Physics 1
data.description: Background of quantum physics. Introduction to formalism of quantum physics. Introduction to operators. Quantization, waves and particles. The uncertainty principle. The Schroedinger equation for one-dimensional problems: bound states in square wells. Harmonic oscillator; transmission through barriers.
data.prerequisites: PHYS 112 or 122; MATH 114 or 136; MATH 128 or 138 or 148.
data.notes: [Note: PHYS 236 or knowledge of computational methods is recommended. Offered: W, S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Computational Physics 1
data.description: Introduction to scientific computer programming techniques as applied to problem solving in physics, with examples from first year mechanics. Procedural programs, control structures, functions, and data storage. Numerical differentiation, integration, and solution of linear equation systems. Data analysis and visualization. [Offered: F]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 111 or 121; Not open to students in Mathematics.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Computational Physics 2
data.description: Object-oriented programming applied to physical problems in astrophysics, electromagnetism, classical and quantum mechanics. Solution methods for differential equations and Monte Carlo techniques. [Offered: W,S]
data.prerequisites: One of PHYS 139, 236, CS 115, 121, 122, 123, 125, 131, 132, 133, 135, 145, CHE 121, CIVE 121, ECE 150, GENE 121, NE 113, SYDE 121; Not open to students in the Faculty of Mathematics

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electricity and Magnetism
data.description: Coulomb's law, electric fields, Gauss' law, electric potential. Capacitance, current, resistance, circuits. Magnetic fields, Ampere's Law, induced electromotive forces, magnetic properties of materials. [Offered: F. The last offering of this course will be fall 2011.]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 111 or 121; PHYS 112 or 122; MATH 128 or 138 or 148.
data.corequisites: PHYS 241L/260A for Science students except Mathematical Physics Plan.
terms_offered: F. The last offering of this course will be fall 2011

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electricity and Magnetism 1
data.description: Coulomb's law, electric fields, Gauss' law, potential, capacitance, properties of dielectrics, DC circuits, AC circuits. [Offered: W,S]
data.prerequisites: One of PHYS 112,122; One of MATH 128, 138, 148; (MATH 227 or co-requisite: AMATH 231).
data.corequisites: PHYS 242L for science students except Mathematical Physics & Materials and Nanosciences plan.
data.notes: [Note: Students with PHYS 122 prior to Winter 2012 need to include PHYS 191 as a prerequisite. Offered: W,S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electricity and Magnetism Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 242.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternates weeks. Offered: W,S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Physical Optics
data.description: Nature of light, wave motion, superposition of waves, interference of light, Fraunhofer diffraction and resolution limit of optical instruments; the diffraction grating and the analysis of light. Fresnel diffraction. Polarized light. Coherence of light, lasers, holography. Fibre Optics. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: One of PHYS 111, 121 and One of PHYS 112, 122; One of MATH 107, 127, 137, 147 and One of MATH 108, 128, 138, 148. Not open to students in Honours Physics or Honours Chemical Physics.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Geometrical and Physical Optics
data.description: Electromagnetic waves and the nature of light. Geometrical optics, aberrations. Physical Optics: interference, Fraunhofer and Fresnel diffraction, polarization. Optical instruments. [Offered: F]
data.corequisites: PHYS 256L for Science students except for Mathematical Physics Plan.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Optics Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 256.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternate weeks. Offered: F]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Intermediate Physics Laboratory
data.description: Experiments in selected physics topics.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternates weeks. Approximately a week before a particular lab is held, a one hour lecture will be given on the material to be covered in the lab. Offered W,S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Astronomical Observations, Instrumentation and Data Analysis
data.description: Telescopes, instrumentation and observations at different wavelengths (radio, sub-millimetre, infrared, optical, X-ray). Probability and statistics. Data archives and data analysis. [Offered: W,S]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 256 or ECE 404.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Astronomical Observations, Instrumentation and Data Analysis Laboratory
data.description: For students who are taking PHYS 270. [Offered: W,S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Planets
data.description: Terrestrial and gas giant planets in the Solar System, asteroids and comets. Extrasolar planets and astrobiology. Star and planet formation. [Offered: F]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 111 or 115 or 121 or ECE 105

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Quantum Physics 2
data.description: Formalism of quantum mechanics. Operator approach to the harmonic oscillator. Quantum mechanics in three dimensions: Hydrogen atom, angular momentum and spin. Time-independent perturbation theory. Fine structure of hydrogen. Zeeman effect. Identical particles. The variational principle. Ground state of the helium atom. Applications in atomic and molecular physics. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 234 or CHEM 356; One of MATH 228, AMATH 250, 251; MATH 227 or 237 or 247.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Condensed Matter Physics
data.description: Overview of condensed matter ordered and disordered systems. Thermodynamic origin of order and phase transitions. Waves. Properties of the solid state. Crystals and fractals. Overview of Fourier Series. Reciprocal lattice. Diffraction. Classical elastic theory of the crystalline state. Electrons in a periodic potential, Band structure and Fermi surface. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 234 or CHEM 356; Level at least 3A Engineering, Mathematics or Science students

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Scientific Computation 2
data.description: Introduction to selected topics in numerical treatment of problems in condensed matter physics, astrophysics, optics, and/or biophysics. Examples of covered computational methods are: Monte Carlo method, Molecular Dynamics, optimization, and solution to partial differential equations. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: One of PHYS 139, CS 115, 121, 122, 123, 125, 131, 132, 133, 135, 145, CHE 121, ECE 150, GENE 121, NE 113, SYDE 121; Honours Physics, Honours Chemistry, Science and Business/Physics, Computational Science, Science and Aviation/Physics

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electricity and Magnetism 2
data.description: Magnetic fields, Ampere's law, induced electromotive forces, magnetic devices, magnetic properties of materials, inductance, introduction to Maxwell's equations and electromagnetic waves.
data.prerequisites: PHYS 242; One of MATH 228, AMATH 250, AMATH 251.
data.notes: [Note: PHYS 236 or knowledge of computational methods recommended. Offered: F, S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Thermal Physics
data.description: Temperature and thermodynamic equilibrium. Work, internal energy and heat; first law, with examples. Kinetic theory of gases. Basic probability theory. Microscopic states and entropy. Absolute temperature, reversibility and the second law. Thermodynamic Functions and Maxwell's relations. Phase transitions. Third Law. Other applications of thermodynamics. [Formerly PHYS 258. Offered: F, S]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 112 or 122; MATH 227 or 237 or 247; One of MATH 228, AMATH 250, AMATH 251.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Statistical Mechanics
data.description: Fundamental postulate of statistical thermodynamics. Entropy. Microcanonical, canonical and grand canonical ensembles. Fermi-Dirac, Bose-Einstein and Boltzmann Statistics. Maxwell-Boltzmann velocity distribution. Applications to specific heat of solids, classical and quantum gases, electrons in metals, Planck's law of radiation, and Bose-Einstein condensation. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: (PHYS 358 or ECE 403 or CHEM 254 or ME 250); (PHYS 233 or 234 or CHEM 356 or co-requisite: AMATH 373).

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Modern Physics Laboratory 1
data.description: Selected experiments in mechanics, optics, electronics, atomic, molecular, nuclear and solid state physics.
data.notes: [Note: There will be 18 hours of experiments. Three year-two physics labs will have to be completed before this lab course is undertaken. Offered: F,W,S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Modern Physics Laboratory 2
data.description: Continuation of 360A.
data.notes: [Note: 18 hours of experiments. Offered: F,W,S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Intermediate Classical Mechanics
data.description: Non-inertial frames of reference. Calculus of variations. Lagrangian mechanics. Coupled oscillations and normal modes. Hamiltonian dynamics.
data.prerequisites: One of PHYS 263, AMATH 261, 271 ; One of MATH 227, 237, 247; One of MATH 228, AMATH 250, AMATH 251
data.notes: [Note: PHYS 236 or knowledge of computational methods recommended. Offered: F,S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Mathematical Physics 1
data.description: Sturm-Liouville theory. Legendre, Bessel and other special functions. Fourier series and introduction to Fourier transforms. Separation of variables. Green's function. [Offered: F,S]
data.prerequisites: MATH 227, MATH 228 or AMATH 250; Honours Physics, Chemical Physics, Physics and Astronomy, Life Physics and Materials and Nanosciences students only.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Mathematical Physics 2
data.description: Introduction to probability and statistics. Complex variables, Cauchy-Riemann conditions, Cauchy integral formula, Taylor and Laurent expansions, residue theorem, contour integrals and applications. Fourier and Laplace transforms with applications. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: MATH 227, 228 or AMATH 250; Honours Physics, Chemical Physics, Physics and Astronomy, Life Physics and Materials and Nanosciences students only.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Cellular Biophysics
data.description: Structure and function of cellular membranes, membrane lipid and protein structure and dynamics, membrane potential and ion transport, nerve conduction, vision and interaction of light with membranes, muscle contraction and energy transduction.
data.prerequisites: One of PHYS 111 or 121 and One of PHYS 112 or 122; One of CHEM 120 or 121 and One of CHEM 123 or 125.
data.notes: [Note: Offered in odd numbered years. Offered: W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Astronomy Laboratory 1
data.description: Selected experiments in astronomy. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 270L

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Stars
data.description: Stellar distances, masses, ages. Stellar interiors and atmospheres, star formation and evolution. Supernovae, white dwarfs, neutron stars, black holes. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 112 or 122 and two of PHYS 234, 242, 256, 275, 358, AMATH 271

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Molecular and Cellular Biophysics
data.description: Cell structure and molecular composition; intermolecular interactions and hydration; protein structure and function; cytoskeletal filaments; DNA structure, packing and chromosomes; rate equations and biological dynamics (e.g., cytoskeletal polymerization); self-assembly; cell membranes; action potentials and biological electricity; molecular motors; cell motility. [Recommended PHYS 280/BIOL 280. Offered: F, S]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 112 or 122; CHEM 123

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Medical Physics
data.description: Applications of physics in medicine. The course will address basic concepts of medical imaging, nuclear medicine and radiation isotopes, radiation therapy and biomedical laser applications. Nuclear structure and binding energy. Nuclear decays, radioactivity and nuclear reactions. Interaction of radiation with matter. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 112 or 122; one of MATH 118, 119, 128, 138, 148; PHYS 280/BIOL 280

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electronics
data.description: p and n materials, pn diodes, junction and FET transistors. Transistor amplifiers and their equivalent circuits. Operational amplifiers. Oscillators and power supplies. Noise. [Formerly PHYS 352. Offered: W even years]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electronics Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 391.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternates weeks. Offered: W even years]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Scientific Measurement and Control
data.description: Logic gates, flip-flops and shift registers, analogue to digital and digital to analogue conversion, feedback control systems, noise and spectral analysis, RF electronics. [Formerly PHYS 353. Offered: W odd years]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Scientific Measurement and Control Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 392.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternates weeks. Offered: W odd years]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Physical Optics
data.description: Fourier Optics: diffraction, dispersion, coherence, imaging. Polarization: birefringence, Jones vectors, Mueller Matrices. Fresnel Equations: optics at an interface, thin films. [Offered: W even years]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 256 or ECE 404; PHYS 364 or AMATH 353

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Light-Matter Interactions
data.description: Lasers: semi-classical interaction, properties, cavity, Gaussian beams. Radiation and Detectors. Introduction to nonlinear optics. [Offered: W odd years]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 256 or ECE 404; PHYS 364 or AMATH 353

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Biophysics of Therapeutic Methods
data.description: The effect of radiation of various kinds on cells and tissues; elements of radiobiology and photobiology; molecular mechanisms of radiation-induced DNA damage and cell death, repair of radiation damage, dose-response relationships; tumor radiobiology and therapies, radiotherapy, photodynamic therapy, combination therapies; radiosensitizers and photosensitizers for cancer therapies; transdisciplinary advances in physical methods (ultrafast laser and ultrasound techniques) for biomedical applications.
data.prerequisites: One of PHYS 112, 122, 125, ECE 106, One of BIOL 130, 239, CHEM 123, PHARM 141, PHYS 280/BIOL 280, PHYS 380; Level at least 3A Science, Mathematics or Engineering students.
data.notes: [Note: PHYS 380 is recommended. Offered: W even years]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Biophysics of Imaging
data.description: Introduction to imaging concepts in biophysics with emphasis on the interrelationship between the physics principles of an imaging modality and the associated image reconstruction; methods for imaging at macroscopic to microscopic scales; computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, ultrasound, PET, optical imaging, optical and fluorescence microscopy, scanning probe microscopy (AFM, STM), optical tweezers, electron microscopy.
data.prerequisites: One of PHYS 112,122,125, ECE106; One of MATH128,138,148, (SYDE 111,112); One of PHYS224,233,234,242,256,280,380, ECE209,370,375, NE232,241, SYDE283, AMATH231,373, CS473, CHEM209,356; Level at least 3A Science, Mathematics or Engineering stdnts.
data.notes: [Note: PHYS 380 recommended. Offered: W odd years]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Quantum Physics 3
data.description: Symmetries and conservation laws. Review of time-independent perturbation theory (degenerate and non-degenerate. Rayleigh-Schrodinger, Brillouin-Wigner and canonical perturbation theory; effective Hamiltonian derivation). Time-dependent perturbation theory (1st and 2nd order, adiabatic perturbation, Aharonov-Bohm effect). Fermi's golden rule. Two-level systems. Emission and absorption of radiation (applications). Second quantization of electromagnetic field in free space; photons. Spontaneous emission and natural lifetime; Lamb shift. Elements of scattering theory. Introduction to the Dirac equation. [Offered: F]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 334 or AMATH 373; PHYS 364 or AMATH 351; PHYS 365 or (AMATH 332 and 353)

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Current Topics in Condensed Matter Physics
data.description: Physics pertaining to collective and emergent phenomena in condensed matter systems. Examples of topics to be covered include: magnetism, superconductivity, heavy Fermion systems, quantum hall effect, protein folding, membranes, DNA physics, polymer physics, Modern experimental and theoretical techniques. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 335, 359; PHYS 334 or AMATH 373

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Research Project
data.description: A research project in any area of Physics approved by the course co-ordinator(s). The student is required to present a summary of the project orally and to submit a written report in a style suitable for publication. Some projects, especially those with an experimental emphasis, will likely continue as 437B. In these cases, students will submit an interim written report, in addition to the oral presentation. [Offered: F,W]
data.prerequisites: Honours Physics, Chemical Physics, Mathematical Physics, Physics and Astronomy, Materials and Nanosciences or Life Physics students only

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electromagnetic Theory
data.description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, and the macroscopic description of dielectrics and magnetic materials. Includes appropriate mathematical techniques, potential theory and the method of images. [Offered: F. The last offering of this course will be fall 2014.]
data.prerequisites: (PHYS 252 and 253) or PHYS 241; PHYS 364, 365 or (AMATH 332, 351, 353)
terms_offered: F. The last offering of this course will be fall 2014

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Research Project (continued)
data.description: A continuation of the project undertaken in PHYS 437A. The student is required to present a summary of the project orally or by poster and to submit a written report in a style suitable for publication. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 437A

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electricity and Magnetism 3
data.description: Review of the origin of Maxwell's equations, conservation laws, potential formulation of Maxwell's equations and gauge choices, vacuum solutions of Maxwell's equations (free space, waveguides, dispersion), solution to Maxwell's equations for arbitrary sources (static and time-dependent problems), relativistic formulation of electrodynamics, macroscopic Maxwell's equations and plane waves in macroscopic media. [Offered: F]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 342; (PHYS 364 and 365) or (AMATH 332 and 351 and 353)

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Introduction to Particle Physics
data.description: This course introduces students to the standard model of particle physics. Topics covered include symmetries, particle classification, experimental methods and tools, scattering, Feynman diagrams, gauge theories, quantum electrodynamics, quarks, quantum chromodynamics, weak interactions, and the Higgs mechanism. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: (PHYS 334 or AMATH 373); PHYS 363; (PHYS 364 and 365) or (AMATH 332, 351, 353)

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Advanced Laboratory 1
data.description: Selected advanced experiments in mechanics, optics, electronics, atomic, molecular, nuclear and solid state physics.
data.prerequisites: PHYS 360A; Fourth Year Physics Majors only
data.notes: [Note: 18 hours of experiments. Offered: F,W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Advanced Laboratory 2
data.description: A continuation of PHYS 460A.
data.prerequisites: PHYS 460A
data.notes: [Note: 18 hours of experiments. Offered: W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Nanophysics
data.description: Fundamentals of nanotechnology. Applications of nanotechnology in biology and medicine. Nanotechnology and society. Physical foundations of nanodevices. Conduction at the nanoscale. Modern nanodevices. [Offered: F]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 335 or ECE 231; Level at least 4A.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Introduction to the Implementation of Quantum Information Processing
data.description: Photonic quantum computing, Superconducting qubits, NMR, Ion Trap quantum computing, Atomic quantum computing. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: CO 481/CS 467/PHYS 467 or PHYS 334

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Cosmology
data.description: Robertson-Walker metric and Friedmann equations. Observational cosmology. Dark matter and dark energy. Gravitational lensing. Big Bang nucleosynthesis, the cosmic microwave background. Inflation. Structure formation.
data.prerequisites: One of AMATH 261, 271, PHYS 263; Level at least 4A in Mathematics or Science
data.notes: [Note: PHYS 474 is recommended. Offered: F]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Radiation Biophysics
data.description: The effect of radiation of various kinds on cells and tissues; mechanisms of damage, repair theories, genetic effects, dose-response relationships; cancer radiotherapy (x-rays, electrons, neutrons, protons, negative Pi mesons); other types of cancer therapies used in conjunction with radiotherapy (e.g. hyperthermia); late effects of radiation; carcinogenesis; risk vs. benefit; applications.
data.prerequisites: One of PHYS 111, 115, 121 and one of PHYS 112, 122, 125 and level at least 4A in Applied Health Sciences, Engineering, Mathematics or Science
data.notes: [Note: First year Physics will become a prerequisite for entry into this course beginning in the Fall of 2010. Offered: F]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special topics in Physics
data.description: A lecture course offered in a particular branch of physics, subject to availability of instructor.
data.prerequisites: Honours Physics or Chemical Physics students only

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Quantum Field Theory 1
data.description: Canonical quantization of fields, perturbation theory, derivation of Feynman diagrams, applications in particle and condensed matter theory, renormalization in phi^4.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Statistical Physics
data.description: A brief review of ensembles and quantum gases, Ising model, Landau theory of phase transitions, order parameters, topology, classical solutions.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Quantum Field Theory 2
data.description:
Feynman Path Integral, abelian and nonabelian guage theories and their quantization, spontaneous symmetry breaking, nonperturbative techniques: 
latticef ield theory, Wilsonian renormalization.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Relativity
data.description: Special relativity, foundations of general relativity, Riemannian geometry, Einstein's equations, FRW and Schwarzschild geometries and their properties

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Quantum Theory
data.description: Schrodinger equation: free particle, harmonic oscillator, simple time-dependent problems.  Heisenbrerg picture and connection with classical physics.  Entaglement and non-locality.  Pure and mixed states, quantum correlators, measurement theory and interpretation.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Information and Data Analysis
data.description: Probability, entropy, Bayesian inference and information theory.  Maximum likelihood methods, common probability distributions, applications to real data including Monte-Carlo methods.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Dynamical Systems
data.description: Maps, flows, stability, fixed points, attractors, chaos, bifurcations, ergodicity, approach to chaos.  Hamiltonian systems, Liouville measure, Poincare theorem, integrable systems with examples.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Computation
data.description: Common algorithms for ode and pde solving, with numerical analysis.  Common tasks in linear algebra.  Focus on how to write a good code, test it, and obtain a reliable result.  Parallel programming.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Conformal Field Theory
data.description: This course is an introduction to the key ideas and techniques of conformal field theories.  These theories play a central role In the study of phase transitions in statistical physics and condensed matter systems, as well as in string theory.  Conformal field theories provide a theoretical laboratory in which the constraints imposed by symmetries allow for the exact solution of field theories, which have found important applications in both physics and mathematics.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Mathematics Physics
data.description: This course will include the study of Perturbation Theory (Regular and Singular) Speeding Up Convergence:  Shanks Transformations and Richardson Extrapolation Taylor Series, Fourier Series and the Gibbs Phenomenon Using Diveregent Series: Generalised Summation Analytic Continuation, Riemann Surfaces and Branch Points Continued Functions and Pade Approximants Steiltjes Functions, the Herglotz Property and the Carleman Bound Feynman Diagrams.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: PSI Condensed Matter Physics
data.description: Theories of Condensed Matter Physics emphasizing the consequences of broken symmetries and the resulting collective modes which emerge, including broken translational symmetry and phonons, broken spin rotational symmetry and magnons, electronic properties of normal metals, and broken U(1) gauge symmetry in superconductors, excitations above the gap and collective modes in superconductors.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Cosmology
data.description: FRW metric, Hubble expansion, dark energy, dark matter, CMB.  Thermodynamic history of early universe.  Growth of perturbations, CDM model of structure formation and comparison to observations, cosmic microwave background anisotropies, inflation and observational tests.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Standard Model
data.description: Application of Yang-Mills theory to particle physics, QCD and its tests in the perturbative regime, theory of weak interactions, precision tests of electroweak theory, CKM matrix and flavour physics, open questions.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International String Theory
data.description: Superstring spectrum in 10d Minkowski, as well as simple toroidal and orbifold compactifications.  T-duality, D-branes, tree amplitudes.  Construct some simple unified models of particle physics.  Motivate the 10- and 11-dimensional supergravities.  Simple supergravity solutions and use these to explore some aspects of AdS/CFT duality.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Mathematical Physics Topics
data.description: Differential forms, de Rham cohomology, differential topology and characteristic classes, monopoles and instantons, Kahler manifolds, Dirac equation, zero modes and index theorems.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Supersymmetry
data.description: The following topics will be discussed:  The Lorentz Group: Properties and Representations; Manipulating Spinors; Supersymmetry Algebra and Representations; Superfields and Superspace; 4d Supersymmetric Lagrangians; Supersymmetry Breaking; Constructing the MSSM; Collider Phenomenology of Supersymmetric Theories; and Dark Matter.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Quantum Information Review
data.description: Review of selected topics in Quantum Information

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Gravitational Physics Review
data.description: Review of selected topics in Gravitational Physics

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Condensed Matter Theory
data.description: Review of selected topics in Condensed Matter Theory

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Quantum Gravity
data.description: Review of selected topics in Quantum Gravity

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Foundations of Quantum Theory
data.description: Review of selected topics in Foundations of Quantum Theory

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Explorations in Quantum Information
data.description: Review of selected topics in Quantum Information

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Explorations in Numerical Gravitational Physics
data.description: Review of selected topics in Gravitational Physics

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Explorations in Condensed Matter Theory
data.description: Review of selected topics in Condensed Matter Theory

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Explorations in Quantum Gravity
data.description: Review of selected topics in quantum Gravity

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Explorations in Foundations of Quantum Theory
data.description: Review of Selected topics in Foundations of Quantum Theory

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Explorations in Particle Physics
data.description: Review of selected topics in Particle Physics

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Explorations in String Theory
data.description: Review of selected topics in String Theory

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Explorations in Complex Systems
data.description: Review of selected topics in Complex Systems

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Explorations in Cosmology
data.description: Review of Selected topics in Cosmology

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Quantum Mechanics 1
data.description: Review of formalism of nonrelativistic quantum mechanics including symmetries and invariance. Approximation methods and scattering theory. Elementary quantum theory of radiation. Introduction to one-particle relativistic wave equations.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Quantum Mechanics 2
data.description: Concepts of relativistic quantum mechanics, elementary quantum field theory, and Feynman diagrams. Application to many particle systems. Students who have not taken PHYS 701 but have an equivalent background in Quantum Mechanics may seek the instructor's consent to register in this course.
data.prerequisites: PHYS 701 or consent of instructor

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Statistical Physics 1
data.description: Statistical basis of thermodynamics; microcanonical, canonical and grand canonical ensembles; quantum statistical mechanics, theory of the density matrix; fluctuations, noise, irreversible thermodynamics; transport theory; application to gases, liquids, solids.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Statistical Physics 2
data.description: Phase transitions. Fluctuation phenomena. Kubo's theory of time correlation functions for transport and spectral properties; applications selected from a variety of topics including linearized hydrodynamics of normal and superfluids, molecular liquids, liquid crystals, surface phenomena, theory of the dielectric constant, etc. Students who have not taken PHYS 704 but have an equivalent background in Statistical Physics may seek the instructor's consent to register in this course.
data.prerequisites: PHYS 704 or consent of instructor

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electromagnetic Theory
data.description: Solutions to Maxwell's equations; radiation theory; normal modes; multipole expansion; Kirchhoff's diffraction theory; radiating point charge; optical theorem. Special relativity; transformation laws for the electromagnetic field; line broadening; dispersion; Kramers-Kronig relations. Magnetohydrodynamics and plasmas.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Applications of Group Theory
data.description: Introduction to group theory; symmetry, the group concept, representation theory, character theory. Applications to molecular vibrations, the solid state, quantum mechanics and crystal field theory.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Green's Function Method
data.description: Review of essential quantum field theory. Zero and finite temperature Green's functions. Applications.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Atomic Physics
data.description: Emphasis on atomic structure and spectroscopy. Review of angular momentum, rotations, Wigner-Eckart theorem, n-j symbols. Energy levels in complex atoms, Hartree-Fock theory, radiative transitions and inner shell processes. Further topics selected with class interest in mind, at least one of which to be taken from current literature.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Molecular Physics
data.description: Angular momentum and the rotation of molecules; introduction to group theory with application to molecular vibrations; principles of molecular spectroscopy; spectra of isolated molecules; intermolecular interactions and their effects on molecular spectra; selected additional topics (e.g., electronic structure of molecules, experimental spectroscopic techniques, neutron scattering, correlation functions, collision induced absorption, extension of group theory to molecular crystals, normal coordinate analysis, etc.).

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Nonlinear Optics
data.description: Laser and nonlinear optics; techniques for controlling laser beams such as mode selection and mode locking; laser spectroscopy.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Nuclear Physics
data.description: Static properties of nuclei; alpha, beta, gamma-decay; two-body systems; nuclear forces; nuclear reactions; single-particle models for spherical and deformed nuclei; shell, collective, interacting boson models.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Subatomic and Nuclear Physcis
data.description: Offered on demand.  Course content depends on topic and instructor.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Intermediate and High Energy Physics
data.description: Strong, electromagnetic and weak interactions. Isospin, strangeness, conservation laws and symmetry principles. Leptons, hadrons, quarks and their classification, formation, interactions and decay.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Subatomic and Nuclear Physics
data.description: Offered on demand.  Course content depends on topic and instructor.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Liquid State Physics
data.description: Physical properties of atomic liquids; distribution functions and equilibrium properties, elementary perturbation theories and integral equation theories; simple metals, simple computer simulation; viral expansions and thermodynamic derivatives of g(r); experimental determination of g(r).

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Solid State Physics 1
data.description: Phonons, electron states, electron-electron interaction, electron-ion interaction, static properties of solids.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Solid State Physics 2
data.description: Transport properties; optical properties; magnetism; superconductivity; disordered systems.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Theoretical Condensed Matter Physics

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Surface Physics
data.description: Offered on demand.  Course content depends on topic and instructor.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
data.description: Offered on demand.  Course content depends on topics and instructor.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Experimental Physics
data.description: Offered on demand.  Course content depends on topic and instructor.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Microprocessors in the Physics Laboratory
data.description: Interfacing and programming of microprocessors for applications in physics, including signal averaging, auto- and cross-correlation analysis, multichannel spectrum analysis, and Fourier transformation. Consideration of hardware versus software methods for optimization of speed and system size.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Optical Electronics
data.description: Optoelectronic component fabrication, light propagation in linear and nonlinear media, optical fiber properties, electro-optic and acousto-optic modulation, spontaneous and stimulated emission, semiconductor lasers and detectors, noise effects in fiber systems.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Experimental Physics
data.description: Offered on demand.  Course content depends on topic and instructor.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Clinical Applications of Physics in Medicine
data.description: This course provides an overview of the application of physics to medicine. The physical concepts underlying the diagnosis and treatment of disease will be explored. Topics will include general imaging principles such as resolution, intensity and contrast; x-ray imaging and computed tomography; radioisotopes and nuclear medicine, SPECT and PET; magnetic resonance imaging; ultrasound imaging and radiation therapy.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Molecular Biophysics
data.description: Physical methods of determining macromolecular structure: energetics, intramolecular and intermolecular forces, with applications to lamellar structures, information storage, DNA and RNA, recognition and rejection of foreign molecules.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Quantum Information Processing
data.description: Offered on demand.  Course content depends on topic and instructor.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in quantum Information Processing
data.description: Offered on demand. Course content depends on topic and instructor.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Lecture and Reading Course
extra: 55  Mnte Carlo Mtds in Stat Phys
65  Monte Carlo Sim in Soft Matter

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Selected Seminar & Module Course
data.description: (for inter-departmental students)

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Physics
extra: 41  Mod Exp Qntm Opt Atm Ensmb

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Inter-Institution Exchange
data.description: At the Director's discretion, a PhD or MSc student may receive course credit for a term of specialized studies at another institution. Formal evaluation is required.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Physics
data.description: Offered on demand.  Course content depends on topic and instructor.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Physics
data.description: Offered on demand.  Course content depends on topic and instructor.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Galactic Structure
data.description: Introduction to statistical theory and distribution laws. Statistical theory of the galactic system. Stellar motions in the solar vicinity. Galactic rotation. Space distribution of stars and their relation to the galaxy. Distribution of various galactic objects. Application to extra-galactic systems.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Fundamentals of Astrophysics
data.description: Multi-wavelength astronomy: radio, infrared, optical and x-ray observations.  Radiative Processes: macroscopic description, thermal and non-thermal emission, scattering, line transitions and plasma effects.  Gravitational Dynamics: potential and orbits, self-gravitating systems, the Collisionless Boltzmann Equation, gravitational encounters.  Fluid Mechanics: simple fluids, soundwaves and shocks, instabilities and transport mechanisms.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Cosmology
data.description: Friedmann-Robertson-Walker metric and dynamics; big bang thermodynamics; nucleosynthesis; recombination; perturbation theory and structure formation; anisotropies in the Cosmic Microwave Background; statistics of cosmological density and velocity fields; galaxy formation; inflation.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Astrophysics
extra: 12  Tpcs in Current Research at UW

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Gravitation and Cosmology
data.description: Offered on demand.  Course content depends on topic and instructor.
extra: 1   Action Principle in GR and E&M

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Inter-university Graduate Course in Biophysics
data.description: This graduate course is offered using the combined biophysical resources of the Universities of Brock, Guelph, McMaster and Waterloo. Three topics constitute the equivalent of a one-term 3 hrs./week graduate course. Information about the course and the selection of individual topics can be obtained from the department course co-ordinator. Registration and credit will occur in the term of the last module.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Gravitation and Cosmology
data.description: Offered on demand.  Course content depends on topics and instructor.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Thermal Physics
data.description: Temperature and thermodynamic equilibrium. Work, internal energy and heat; first law, with examples. Kinetic theory of gases. Basic probability theory. Microscopic states and entropy. Absolute temperature, reversibility and the second law. Thermodynamic Functions and Maxwell's relations. Phase transitions. Third Law. Other applications of thermodynamics. [Formerly PHYS 258. Offered: F, S]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 112 or 122; MATH 227 or 237 or 247; One of MATH 228, AMATH 250, AMATH 251.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electricity and Magnetism Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 242.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternates weeks. Offered: W,S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Optics Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 256.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternate weeks. Offered: F]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Intermediate Physics Laboratory
data.description: Experiments in selected physics topics.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternates weeks. Approximately a week before a particular lab is held, a one hour lecture will be given on the material to be covered in the lab. Offered W,S]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Introduction to Gravitational Physics
data.description: The basic physical and geometrical ideas underlying Einstein's model of space, time and gravity -- special and general relativity -- with a minimum of mathematical detail. Main topics: (1) Gravitational physics: overview of current research and applications, (2) Special relativity: the geometry of flat spacetime and accelerated observers, and (3) General relativity: geodesics, geometrical formulation of Newtonian gravity, Schwarzschild spacetime and the classical tests of general relativity, and introduction to Einstein's equation. [Offered W]
data.prerequisites: One of (PHYS 111, 112) or (115, 125) or (121, 122) and (one of MATH 108, 118, 119, 128, 138, 148) and (one of MATH 207, 212, 217, 227, 237, 247, AMATH 231) and either (MATH 218 or 228 or AMATH 250) or

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electronics
data.description: p and n materials, pn diodes, junction and FET transistors. Transistor amplifiers and their equivalent circuits. Operational amplifiers. Oscillators and power supplies. Noise. [Formerly PHYS 352. Offered: W even years]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electronics Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 391.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternates weeks. Offered: W even years]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Scientific Measurement and Control
data.description: Logic gates, flip-flops and shift registers, analogue to digital and digital to analogue conversion, feedback control systems, noise and spectral analysis, RF electronics. [Formerly PHYS 353. Offered: W odd years]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Scientific Measurement and Control Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 392.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternates weeks. Offered: W odd years]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Introduction to Communication and Optical Communication Physics
data.description: An introduction to optical fibre, waveguides, and passive optical devices. An overview of semiconductors, light emitting diodes, semiconductor lasers and detectors. Modulation schemes, noise sources and signal detection techniques in communications and optical communications. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: (PHYS 241 or 253) and ( PHYS 125 or 256).

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Introduction to Communication and Optical communication Physics Laboratory
data.description: For students who have taken or are taking PHYS 356.
data.notes: [Note: Lab alternate weeks. Offered: W]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Physics of Solid State Devices
data.description: The theories of solid state physics are applied to explain the operation and use of several electronic devices, including the p-n junction, transistors, tunnel diodes, field effect devices, opto-electronic devices, etc. [Offered: W]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 335 or ECE 209 or NE 242

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electromagnetic Theory
data.description: Maxwell's Equations. Electromagnetic fields and the Lorentz Transformation. Plane waves in insulators, conductors and plasmas. Reflection and refraction at plane boundaries. Guided waves. Dipole radiation. [Offered: W. The last offering of this course will be winter 2015.]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 441A
terms_offered: W. The last offering of this course will be winter 2015

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Modern Optics
data.description: Basic electromagnetic wave theory. Polarization, reflection, refraction, and dispersion. Temporal coherence and spectra. Spatial coherence and diffraction. Spatial filtering. Lasers, modes and beam propagation. Special topics may include crystal optics and nonlinear effects, holography, fibre optics and communications. [Offered: W. The last offering of this course will be winter 2013.]
data.prerequisites: PHYS 256
terms_offered: W. The last offering of this course will be winter 2013

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Biophysics of Imaging
data.description: Introduction to imaging concepts in biophysics with emphasis on the interrelationship between the physics principles of an imaging modality and the associated image reconstruction; methods for imaging at macroscopic to microscopic scales; computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, ultrasound, PET, optical imaging, optical and fluorescence microscopy, scanning probe microscopy (AFM, STM), optical tweezers, electron microscopy.
data.prerequisites: One of PHYS 112,122,125, ECE106; One of MATH128,138,148, (SYDE 111,112); One of PHYS224,233,234,242,256,280,380, ECE209,370,375, NE232,241, SYDE283, AMATH231,373, CS473, CHEM209,356; Level at least 3A Science, Mathematics or Engineering stdnts.
data.notes: [Note: PHYS 380 recommended. Offered: W odd years]

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Electron Microscopy and Electron Diffraction
data.description: Introduction to electron optics and the electron microscope; kinematical and dynamical theories of electron diffraction by perfect crystals and by crystals containing lattice imperfections, limited area electron diffraction, dark-field microscopy, interpretation of electron diffraction patterns and diffraction contrast effects in electron microscope images, selected experimental methods in electron microscopy.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Basic Theory of Nuclear Magnetic Resonance
data.description: Quantum mechanics of spins in magnetic field; Bloch equations; NMR apparatus; the various nuclear spin interactions; spin temperature; density matrix; spin-lattice relaxation; double resonance.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Radiation Biophysics
data.description: Physical properties and biological effects of different kinds of radiation: action of radiation on various cellular constituents: target theory, genetic effects, repair of radiation damage, physics of radiology and radiotherapy, isotopic tracers.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Biophysics of Organ Systems
data.description: Specialized cells and organs; the nerve impulse and its propagation, muscle contraction, sensory transducers, the central nervous system; haemodynamics, the red blood corpuscle, homeostasis; selected topics of current interest, and seminar.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Perimeter Scholars International Explorations in Quantum Gravity
data.description: This course will introduce the students to the basic techniques and results of the field of loop quantum gravity.  Possible topics include: 1) The Ashtekar variables and the Hamiltonian formalism; 2) The Plebanski action for general relativity; 3) The Hilbert space of loop quantum gravity and basic operators such as the area and volume operators; 4) Spin foam models; 5) Group field theory; 6) Quantum black hole horizons.

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Galaxies
data.description: Galaxy structure, formation and evolution. Dynamics and stellar populations; gas and dust; supermassive black holes; large-scale structure. [Offered: F]
data.prerequisites: AMATH 261 or 271 or PHYS 263; PHYS 375; Level at least 4A Mathematics or Science

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Advanced Therapeutic Concepts in Oncology and Medical Physics
data.description:
This course examines advanced oncology therapeutic concepts required as a foundation for patient management in the inpatient, ambulatory, and community settings. Topics include a comprehensive review of cancer epidemiology and pathophysiology, therapeutic agents used in the oncology setting, management of cancer therapy toxicities, and treatment and palliation of cancer symptoms. Physics methods in radiation therapy and the medical physicist's role in cancer treatment will be addressed. [Offered: W]
[Held with PHARM 464]
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A Life Physics, Medical Physics Specialization

data.subject: PHYS
data.title: Special Topics in Life, Medical and Biophysics
data.description:
A lecture and project course offered in areas of life, medical and biophysics, which will add to the learning experience of the students in these plans at a fourth year level. Lecture topics may include advanced topics in: molecular and cellular biophysics, imaging, biophotonics, interaction of radiation with biomaterials, radiation dosimetry and other physics based diagnostics and therapeutics. Projects may include studies of recent advances in any areas of medical and biophysics. 
[Offered: F]
data.prerequisites: Level at least 4A; one of PHYS 380, 383, 395, 396
